MacOS Safari cannot install extension solution
item.description: <p>Some old MacOS user may notice that installing Safari extention is not working like before in new system. &#x201C;Install now&#x201D; is no longer exist, it was replaced by &#x201C;Trust&#x201D;. However, when click the &#x201C;Trust&#x201D; button to install external extension, extension will not be installed in to Safari. That has nothing to do with the extension compatible issue.</p> <p>This seems like a bug on the &#x201C;Trust&#x201D; button. Mouse click on the &#x201C;Trust&#x201D; button is ignored. However, there is a trick to get this work. We can use keyboard to confirm the installation. Before that, we need to enable the keyboard control access in Windows and dialogs. For OS X 10.11.* or maybe later version if bug still exist. Go to System Preferences &gt; Keyboard &gt; Shortcuts &gt; Full Keyboard Access, select &#x201C;All controls&#x201D;. Now we can press Tab key to move focus between button in Windows and dialogs. <img src="/2016/04/osx-10.11-keyboard-all-controls.png" alt="Osx 10.11 Keyboard All Controls"> Now try to install Safari extension, when the dialog pop up, do not use mouse to click the &#x201C;Trust&#x201D; button since it will not work, use keyboard instead. Press the &#x201C;tab&#x201D; key to move the focus to &#x201C;Trust&#x201D; button and hit space or return. Extension will be installed.</p>

Rename network name for MAC OS X
item.description: <p>Network name is the unique name that differentiate a MAC or PC on a network. If you have more than one MAC and you start sharing things back and forth between your computers, the names of those MACs start to matter. </p> <p>On Mac OS X, changing computer name is extremely easy. How to change it? Just open up System Preferences, go to Sharing, and change the computer name. <img src="/2015/07/OS-X-System-Preferences.png" alt="Os X System Preferences"> You may need to change the name under your Network setting also. Open&#xA0;Network (next to Sharing), Advanced, WINS, and change the NetBIOS name. Done!</p>

Still need DOS? Create a Bootable MS-DOS / FreeDOS USB Drive
item.description: <p>Does we still need DOS for somethings? Yes, if you are still using Ghost for backup and restore. Or you need data recovery software work only under DOS. BIOS updates, firmware-updating utilities often require you to boot into DOS and run the utility. However, it is extremely hard to find a floppy disks with MS-DOS or a computer can read floppy disks anymore. If you still need DOS to do some operations, you can create a bootable DOS USB drive. Burning ISO to USB can be a headache for a lot of people, and oftentimes it will split a USB drive into two partitions. Here we have a tool Rufus to do this simple but not easy job for us. Rufus will not split USB to multiple partitions so the remaining portion of the drive can still be used. Download <a href="http://rufus.akeo.ie/">Rufus</a> Rufus doesn&#x2019;t need any installation so you just launch it after you downloaded it. <img src="/2014/10/rufus.png" alt="Rufus"> Now we can create a bootable USB drive with DOS in a very simple way:</p> <h2 id="1-Connect-a-USB-drive-to-the-computer-and-select-it-in-the-Device-box"><a href="#1-Connect-a-USB-drive-to-the-computer-and-select-it-in-the-Device-box" class="headerlink" title="1. Connect a USB drive to the computer and select it in the Device box."></a>1. Connect a USB drive to the computer and select it in the Device box.</h2><h2 id="2-Check-&#x201C;Create-a-bootable-disk-using&#x201D;-checkbox-and-select-MS-DOS-or-FreeDOS"><a href="#2-Check-&#x201C;Create-a-bootable-disk-using&#x201D;-checkbox-and-select-MS-DOS-or-FreeDOS" class="headerlink" title="2. Check &#x201C;Create a bootable disk using&#x201D; checkbox and select MS-DOS or FreeDOS."></a>2. Check &#x201C;Create a bootable disk using&#x201D; checkbox and select MS-DOS or FreeDOS.</h2><h2 id="3-Click-the-Start-button-This-will-erase-the-contents-of-your-USB-drive"><a href="#3-Click-the-Start-button-This-will-erase-the-contents-of-your-USB-drive" class="headerlink" title="3. Click the Start button. This will erase the contents of your USB drive."></a>3. Click the Start button. This will erase the contents of your USB drive.</h2><p>You can also use Refus to create a bootable USB from an ISO image. You can even use it to create a Windows 8 installation USB drive. *Since version 1.3.2, Rufus support UEFI as well as GPT for installation media, meaning that it will allow you to install Windows 7, Windows 8 or Linux in full EFI mode. Because of OS limitations, Windows XP restricts the creation of UEFI bootable drives to MBR mode.</p>

Open Source FREE Automatic Periodic Screen Capture Tool
item.description: <p>AutoScreenCap is a lightweight Open Source screen capture tool. It is a small software does like what its name describes: auto screen capture. It allows you to make screen shots periodically and automatically save to the folder in JPG format. It is fully customizable, the capture interval can be set from 1 second to 99999 and the JPG quality also adjustable. It can be set to auto hide the main windows and auto start screenshot capture for special purposes. <img src="/2014/09/autoscreencap.jpg" alt="Autoscreencap"> </p> <p>Although the last update of this tool is back in 2012, this software still work fine in the latest Windows 8.1 64 bit. <a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/autoscreencap/files/latest/download?source=files" title="autoscreencap download">Click here to download the latest version AutoScreenCap</a> It does not require installation. So basically extract the zip file to a folder and run AutoScreenCap.exe</p>
